title: The Shroud of Turin Exposition on Social Media
post: If he is the archbishop of Turin, he is not a Msgr. (monsignor).
author: Andy

title: The Shroud of Turin Exposition on Social Media
post: You tried that before, Andy, without any justification. Would you like to explain why you think it? It may be that Cesare Nosiglia was never a Monsignor as such, as it seems to be a normal way of describing any bishop in some languages, whether he was previously a monsignor or not, but if he was, I do not think that the honorific lapses just because of one’s elevation to episcopacy.
author: Hugh Farey

title: The Shroud of Turin Exposition on Social Media
post: Andy, look at the Monsignor bishop’s official page on the diocesan website at http://www.diocesitorino.it/diocesi_di_torino/arcivescovo/00024135_Arcivescovo.html.  He signs his name Mons. Cesare Nosiglia, Archbishop of Turin. I’m told the honorific title Monsignor, which the pope is all but eliminating anyway, may be conferred on a deacon, priest or bishop and used for life.
author: Dan
